awd_titl_txt: Cold Atom-Ion Charge-Exchange and Internal Molecular-Ion Sympathetic Cooling in an Ion-Neutral Hybrid Trap
awd_abstract_narration:
This research uses an innovative hybrid ion-neutral atomic particle trap developed by the PI's group as a tool for observing reactions and collisions of low energy ions with atoms cooled by lasers to near absolute zero temperature (~0.001 Kelvin).  The cold atoms within a magneto-optic trap (MOT) can be used to refrigerate a co-trapped sample of atomic or molecular ions to study ion-atom interactions at temperatures approaching that of space. Cold, trapped Na+ and Ca+ atomic ion, and Na2+ molecular ion reaction rates with ultracold sodium (Na) atoms will be measured, as well as the rates of sympathetic collisional cooling, using the hybrid trap.  The research has technical applications to precision spectroscopy, fundamental constants, astrophysical processes in the solar system and interstellar medium, atomic ion clocks and quantum computing.  The ion-neutral hybrid trap combines two separate but spatially overlapped and concentric traps: a MOT and a Paul radiofrequency ion trap. Specifically, the project will involve direct experimental measurements of the absolute electron-exchange rate constant between Na and Ca+, investigating its dependence on collision energy and ionic and/or atomic excited-state populations. The rates will be compared with simulations. The resonance radiation absorption spectrum of trapped Ca+ ions will be investigated as a temperature probe of the trap as will the possibility of forming small lattices of confined, ionic Coulomb "crystals" inside the trap by using sympathetic cooling collisions, rather than traditional laser cooling.

A graduate student completed his Ph.D. in experimental atomic physics under the previous NSF grant and two additional Ph.D. level students expect to complete their ongoing dissertation research under the new grant.  An undergraduate physics-mathematics student worked on simulations during the previous grant, as well as two M.S.-level exchange students from the University of Heidelberg, who did experimental work.  Both undergraduate and graduate physics students participate in independent study work on this project.  Students receive a broad education in basic experimental techniques of atomic and molecular physics: laser and collisional cooling and trapping at high vacuum (conditions resembling those of space), as well as cold ion manipulation, trapping, detection and laser spectroscopy. The PI gave an invited talk on this hybrid trap research in 2013 at a symposium on the Sao Carlos campus of the University of Sao Paulo, Brazil, attended by 5 physics Nobel Laureates. Research results are frequently presented in publications and at local, national and international meetings.

por.por_cntn:
A hybrid atomic ion-neutral atom particle trap, developed under previous NSF grants, has been used as a new research tool to observe simple chemical reactions and collisions of cold (low-energy) ions with laser-cooled neutral atoms. The effective temperature of these collisions can be 1 degree Kelvin or less, i.e. near absolute-zero. Cold to ultracold ion-neutral interactions were relatively unexplored until the development of the hybrid trap, such as we use. The hybrid trap we have developed is a combination of a cold-atom magneto-optic trap (MOT) plus a concentric linear Paul radiofrequency (r.f.) ion trap. [The MOT uses a combination of a static inhomogeneous magnetic field and 3 perpendicular pairs of laser beams to confine and cool neutral atoms (sodium) to a temperature near absolute zero (about 0.001 degree Kelvin), under high vacuum. Ions, because of their electric charge, cannot be stably trapped in static electric fields according to Ehrenfest's theorem and Maxwell's equations, which is why the Paul ion trap is used with rapidly alternating r.f. electric fields. Optical forces, using special monochromatic laser beams, are then used in addition to cool the trapped ion cloud to low temperatures. Our group and other research groups have been able to cool Ca+ ions in the Paul trap in this way below 1 degree Kelvin or to within 1 degree of absolute zero. Below 0.001 Kelvin, for small numbers of ions, a "Coulomb" crystal of ions can be formed. The crystal is due to a balance of repulsive electric forces between the ions and the trapping confining forces from the Paul ion trap. We have imaged a crystalline array of ions thus formed using fluorescence from scattered beams of near UV 397 nm laser light, the same light that is used to cool the ions to low temperature in the first place.]

The goal in the current 2-year grant and extensions is to measure scattering and simple electron-transfer reactions (charge exchange) of sodium or calcium ions interacting with ground and laser-excited sodium atoms. The charge-exchange reaction rates for ion-neutral collisions at low temperatures are much larger than chemical reaction rates among neutral atoms at the same temperature, by factors up to 1000 or more.  This means the reactions can be observed even at ultrahigh vacuum, comparable to the vacuum in interplanetary space. In fact, one of the applications of this work is to understand chemical processes that occur in space that may play a role in star formation and the astrophysical processes in the early universe.  Other applications include using a laser-cooled sample of atomic ions to "sympathetically" cool both the translational motion as well as the internal rotational or vibrational energy of a cloud of neutral molecules, which are very difficult to cool by other means. Studying cold reactions of these molecules among themselves or with ions in the sub-Kelvin regime brings to light quantum aspects of the reacting systems, where the wavelike quantum-mechanical nature of low velocity particles becomes important. The study of ion-neutral interactions is relevant to the understanding of both beneficial and detrimental chemical or environmental effects associated with high precision trapped-ion atomic  clocks and ion-based quantum computing schemes.

The main results of this work are published or submitted in 7 peer-reviewed papers since 2013 in major research journals, including 1 invited paper reviewing some of our early hybrid trap charge-exchange rate measurements in a special issue [v. 114, issues 1 and 2, p. 75] of Applied Physics B Lasers and Optics commemorating the 100th birthday of Nobelist Wolfgang Paul (2014), who invented the Paul ion trap. 3 more of these papers are published in Physical Review A (PRA) and 1 paper describing the latest work was submitted recently to PRA. 2 instrumentation-technique papers were published in Review of Scientific Instruments: one (2016) describing techniques for computer-based (offset) locking of multiple lasers to a stabilized reference laser and another paper (2013) describes how to use alternating resonant electric fields in a Paul trap to remove unwanted atomic ions from an ion cloud depending on their mass (mass-selective resonant quenching) and the unwanted heating effects that can occur on the remaining ions. The main result of the just-submitted PRA paper is to measure the 4 reaction rates vs. electronic state of the Ca+ ion reactants (ground or metastable excited D state) on neutral Na atoms (ground or optically-excited P state) and to compare these rates with the classical (Langevin) limits, to elucidate quantum effects. The Langevin limit depends on the probability of a cold ion being captured into a close encounter by the nearby neutral atom. The other PRA papers deal with ion-neutral scattering rates in the hybrid trap and experimental properties of the MOT and the ion trap.

Since 2013, 3 Ph.D.'s graduated and 3 undergraduates performed summer research. There was outreach to high school students and teachers.
